last_post.content:
So, quite a big bunch of us get mentioned in this great article! I miss those days. Mathstodon seems to have quieted down lately. I haven't been in the mood for coming up with problems lots of people can work on, and I don't see other people doing too much of it either. Maybe we all needed to get back to real work.

The full article is here, paywalled:

https://www.nytimes.com/2023/02/07/science/puzzles-rectangles-mathematics.html

but @nev pointed out it's also free here:

https://web.archive.org/web/20230207080644/https://www.nytimes.com/2023/02/07/science/puzzles-rectangles-mathematics.html

title: Napoléon Part I - From Corsica to Paris - La Fayette, We Are Here!

last_post.content:
#OTD in 1807, pyrrhic and indecisive French victory at the battle of Eylau, against the Russians and Prussians. The losses are so horrible that Napoléon stated: “If all the kings of the earth could view such a spectacle, they would be less keen on wars and conquest”.

One of the most remarkable moments of the battle was Murat’s cavalry charge. At 12,000 strong, it is one of the biggest cavalry charges ever. It was essential in preventing a French collapse during the battle. Nevertheless, Ney will say “What a massacre! And all this for nothing!”

The war will drag on for months. Only the decisive French victory of Friedland in June 1807 will lead to the treaty of Tilsit with Alexander I a month later, ending the war of the 4th Coalition and making Russia France’s partner in the continental system… for a time anyway.

To learn more about Napoléon’s rise to power, listen to our latest episode.

last_post.content:
An excellent JS performance experiment by @jakebailey ⚡

Modifying the TypeScript compiler itself so that `let`/`const` become `var` reduces parsing time by ~10% 😲

This is on V8 10.2

One theory is that the perf penalty is due to TDZ checks when using `let`/`const`

Maybe results in Bun/JSC will be different?

Nothing is conclusive. The PR is unlikely to be merged.

The investigation continues... 😉

Big data visualization is about quoting less-aggregated data.

This network can be seen without 3D glasses. But with it, by just blinking, you can switch from the aggregated annotation layer to the less-aggregated original data, a network of expressions from academic papers about AI in science.

You can look "inside" the aggregation, and possibly challenge it. The same way quoting a text allows the reader to challenge what *you* say it says.

title: AI Art and the Problem of Consent

last_post.content:
"AI Art and the Problem of Consent" is a great piece by Mat Dryhurst, in the Art Review. Reads almost like a manifesto.

https://artreview.com/ai-art-and-the-problem-of-consent/

"The polar ideologies of free culture or rigid IP protectionism of the last century feel insufficient for tackling an issue that promises to mutate into a long culture war." writes Mat. And argues that consent is the missing bit.

This is something that we have been studying at @openfuture with regard to the use of photos of faces in face recognition training. This is structurally a similar conversation, only concerning creative outputs instead of visages (there's an interesting overlap between the two, by the way).

Yet while in our case the answer we heard very quickly was "this is not a copyright issue", what Mat writes about is a case that will reopen all key copyright debates: on fair use, exceptions, user rights, remuneration of artists.

And I would argue with Mat that free culture offers a good foundation for tackling the issue. Though I agree that it needs to expand its toolkit. But the vision of a digital, creative commons still holds true.
